feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued August 23 at 11:30AM AKDT until August 23 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WIND ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM AKDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...South winds gusting to 50 mph expected. * WHERE...From Black Rapids north. * WHEN...Until 7 PM AKDT this evening. * IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 11:29AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...RISING WATER LEVELS ON SMALL STREAMS AND CREEKS DRAINING THE BROOKS RANGE... A series of fronts will impact the region, bringing copious amounts of widespread rain that will cause water levels to rise on small streams and creeks draining the south slopes of the Western Brooks Range.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Upper Kobuk and Noatak Valleys

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 11:29AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ..ELEVATED SURF LIKELY ON THURSDAY AND FRIDAY... Strong south winds to 25 to 40 mph will move into the West Coast and bring elevated surf to parts of Norton Sound and the Yukon Delta on Thursday, persisting into Friday before they diminish. Wave action will combine with storm surge and be the greatest along south facing coastlines, with anticipated storm surge
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Yukon Delta

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 5:03AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAVY RAIN TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY... A couple of waves moving N along a stalled front over the central gulf will bring periods of moderate to heavy rain to the NE gulf coast Tuesday into Wednesday. Rain amounts will range from 1.5 to 3 inches with locally higher amounts possible. The heaviest precipitation will be from Tuesday night through Wednesday morning
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Fairweather to Cape Suckling Coastal Area

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 21 at 1:12PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Glacier Dammed lake release causing debris to flow into Controller Bay... Satellite observations indicate that the Berg glacier dammed lake, located 65 miles east of Cordova, has likely released downstream into the Gandil River, Bering River and Bering Lake. High water from this glacier dammed lake release usually lasts for several days with large areas

entry.summary: ...HEAT INDEX VALUES BETWEEN 105 AND 109 DEGREES ARE EXPECTED TODAY... The combination of warm temperatures and high dewpoints will produce heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees today. A few locations may briefly reach 110 degrees. Residents with outdoor activities planned are urged to drink plenty of water, wear light weight and light colored clothing and take frequent breaks from

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 22 at 10:40AM CDT until August 25 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Texas... Trinity River Near Rosser affecting Kaufman and Ellis Counties. For the Trinity River...including Dallas, Rosser, Trinidad, Long Lake (Oakwood)...elevated river levels are forecast. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 1:58PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of south central Hot Springs and central Fremont Counties through 230 PM MDT... At 157 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 11 miles southeast of Anchor Dam to Fort Washakie. Movement was east at 20 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lander Foothills; Owl Creek and Bridger Mountains; Southwest Big Horn Basin; Wind River Basin

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 1:38PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southeastern Niobrara County through 215 PM MDT... At 137 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 13 miles west of Harrison, or 16 miles east of Lusk. This storm was nearly stationary. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 30 mph and half inch hail.
